Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Low-Loss Ad-Hoc Networking for Outdoor WiFi
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project enables connectivity in otherwise difficult areas. Broadband access in rural America, for example, has been a lasting problem that inhibits business and education alike. The primary barrier to installation is the cost of trenching cable, which can be $7,000-$30,000 per service location. Similar challenges exist in emerging markets and remote industrial Internet of Things. Networks cannot easily be replaced with today?s wireless technologies due to the losses that occur when forwarding information wirelessly, which can eliminate up to half of the throughput capability at each forwarding location. Low-loss mesh networking, such as that proposed, would enable fully-wireless solutions to last-mile connectivity problems globally by eliminating reliance on cable. The impact of distributed and scalable algorithms extends beyond mesh networking into the decentralization of other technologies to be more secure and robust, but cannot due to performance issues.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is focused on low-loss mesh networking that could feasibly cover hundreds or thousands of acres with broadband internet access without laying cable. The primary intellectual merits include scalable aggregation of data, reducing communication interference with a predetermined network structure, and other challenges that arise in very large wireless networks. The objective of this research is a wireless mesh network topology and hardware that can maintain less than 17% throughput loss-per-hop in a network larger than 100 nodes. This will be accomplished through real-world trials, simulations, and iterated testing of different geometries and time-domain multiplexing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MeshPlusPlus, Inc. has completed research into “Low-Loss Ad-Hoc Networking for Outdoor WiFi” sponsored by a NSF SBIR Phase I grant. The purpose of the grant was to explore a large-scale, low-loss mesh networking protocol for last-mile broadband internet coverage by building it into solar-powered hardware ‘nodes.’ By minimizing reliance on costly and time-consuming cable trenching, the financial sustainability of rural and remote internet access can be greatly improved.

The main product of this research was the prototyping and production design of a solar-powered mesh WiFi node capable of running a low-loss ad-hoc protocol, as well as data collection on the protocol itself. Such a solar-powered product can operate indefinitely without a power grid and with very little downtime. The primary challenge in vetting wide-area mesh technology is the collection of real-world data at scale, which requires very large networks to be installed. Prior simulations were helpful but not sufficient to make performance claims. Over the course of this grant, two-hundred test nodes were built, of which twenty-seven are installed in permanent testing fixtures in Chicago alone. Eight months of data collected on link bitrates, signal strength, uptime, and other characteristics over a series of firmware revisions are collected.

The SBIR Phase I grant was successful in determining the commercial viability of a low-loss, solar-powered mesh network. A scalable product, demonstrable best-practices, and a telemetry platform was shaped under this grant. Using the test fixtures and hardware created, many future optimizations can be made and used to scale installations into underserved locations in America. The next steps for this project include FCC approval, larger-scale installations (>100 nodes), and early revenue indicating the potential for commercial success.
